Title: RM4123 – L0524 – "As Is" requirements of Royal Mail Pension Scheme
Description:
Please note that this document is being published for Transparency purposes only. This is not a call for competition. Royal Mail Pension Scheme was established in April 2012. The current administrators of this scheme are Royal Mail PSC, who have been administering pensions for the Royal Mail for the last 50 years. The Royal Mail Pension Scheme is now the responsibility of the Cabinet Office, and as such the Cabinet Office will be going out to tender to let a new contract for pension administration. In order to inform that procurement, they have a requirement to set out the “as is” situation with the Royal Mail Pension Scheme. This is the Consultancy Value Statement required for all consultancy contracts. The original contract was published on the Archived Contracts Finder and can be found at the following link:
http://data.gov.uk/data/contracts-finder-archive/contract/1555594/

Title: Pension Administrator: Royal Mail Statutory Pension Scheme
Description: Procurement of a supplier of pension administration services for Royal Mail Statutory Pension Scheme(RMSPS). This scheme is managed by the Authority. The RMSPS transferred to the public sector in April 2012 and the former contract expired in March 2017. The Authority sought innovative proposals to this significant pension administration services opportunity. This procurement is solely for the pension administration services to the RMSPS. The successful pension administrator will work with Royal Mail Pension Plan's (RMPP) pension administrator, Royal Mail Group Limited (RMG), with regard to those members who are beneficiaries in both RMSPS and RMPP. RMSPS is currently the 6th largest public sector pension scheme in the United Kingdom. The RMSPS has approximately 402 000 deferred members and pensioners. Approximately 116 000 of these are also members of the RMPP. The scheme has no active members so there are no accruing costs or contributions.
Attachments: Pension Administration Services Agreement - T&Cs and Schedule 1 (Definitions) - (REDACTED).pdf Schedule 2.1 - Services Description - Final (REDACTED).pdf Schedule 2.2 - Performance Levels - Final (REDACTED).pdf Schedule 2.3 - Standards - Final.pdf Schedule 2.4 - Security Management - Final (REDACTED).pdf Schedule 2.5 - Insurance Requirements - Final (REDACTED).pdf Schedule 3 - Authority Responsibilities - Final (REDACTIONS).pdf Schedule 4.1 - Supplier Solution - Final (REDACTED).pdf Schedule 4.2 - Commercially Sensitive Information - Final (REDACTED).pdf Schedule 4.3 - Notified Key Sub-Contractors - Final (REDACTED).pdf Schedule 4.4 - Third Party Contracts - Final (REDACTED).pdf Schedule 5 - Software - Final (REDACTED).pdf Schedule 6.1 - Implementation Plan - Final (REDACTED).pdf Schedule 6.2 - Testing Procedures - Final.pdf Schedule 7.1 - Charges and Invoicing - Final (REDACTED).pdf Schedule 7.2 - Payments on Termination - Final (REDACTED).pdf Schedule 7.3 - Benchmarking - Final (REDACTED).pdf Schedule 7.5 - Financial Reports and Audit Rights - Final.pdf Schedule 8.1 - Governance - Final (REDACT WHOLE DOC).pdf Schedule 8.2 - Change Control Procedure - Final.pdf Schedule 8.3 - Dispute Resolution Procedure - Final.pdf Schedule 8.4 - Reports and Records Provisions - Final.pdf Schedule 8.5 - Exit Management - Final.pdf Schedule 8.6 - Business Continuity and Disaster Recovery - Final (REDACTED).pdf Schedule 8.7 - Conduct of Claims - Final.pdf Schedule 9.1 - Staff Transfer - Final (REDACTED).pdf Schedule 9.2 - Key Personnel - Final (REDACTED).pdf Schedule 10 - Guarantee - Final (REDACTED).pdf
Additional Text:
Pension Administration services against the following two membership profiles:(1) RMSPS scheme members with no benefits in the RMPP (which amounts to approximately 286 000 members comprised of116 000 deferred members and 170 000 pensioners) and (2) RMSPS scheme members with benefits in the RMPP (which amounts to approximately 116 000 members comprised of 97 000 deferred members and 19000 pensioners). The pension administration services available include the following:- accounting
services, administration services, interactions with members, member communications (including managing and operating a helpline, issuing benefits statements, annual pension increase letters,printing services and also scheme leaflets), pension payroll services (bulk and individual payroll services) and reporting. Membership profile 2 also includes the requirement to work with RMPP's pension administration services provider with regard to those members who are beneficiaries in both the RMSPS and RMPP.

Title: RFQ for the Distribution of Inside Halton Magazine to Residential Properties in Halton via Royal Mail 'Door to Door' Services
Description:
Halton Borough Council intends to procure a suitably qualified organisation, which are capable of distributing the Council?s ?Inside Halton? Magazine via ?Royal Mail? Door to Door services (three times a year) throughout the borough.

The main purpose of ?Inside Halton? Magazine is to keep Halton residents up to date with news and information within the Borough.  

The requirement of Halton Borough Council is outlined below, but maybe subject to change over the period of the contract: -

?	Inside Halton is currently an 28 page, A4 magazine, weighs 80gsm and is unpackaged
?	Delivery currently set at three (3) times per year in March, July and November
?	Distribution must be completed via ?Royal Mail? Door to Door Services within 5 working days of receipt
?	Approximately 55,000 copies to be delivered to all Halton addresses (including parishes)
?	300 copies to be delivered to Halton Borough Council, Municipal Building WA8 7QF

Title: Defra group Mailroom Solutions: Self-Service Mailroom Solutions
Description:
Mailroom Solutions for the Defra Group.

This call-off contract covers all mail services provided under the Crown Commercial Services framework ref. RM1063 Postal Goods and Services, lots 1 & 4 only.

LOT 1: COLLECTION AND DELIVERY - covers the collection and delivery of physical mail items of up to 2kg for public sector customers throughout the whole of the United Kingdom. Services under lot 1 include but are not limited to: bulk mail; standard mailings; sorted and unsorted mail; unaddressed mail; secured mail; undelivered mail; and some bespoke requirements as defined by the contracting body within the mail profile.

LOT 4: INTERNATIONAL MAIL SERVICES - covers the provision of international mail services, including the collection of mail items from public sector customers from all areas of the United Kingdom for delivery to recipients around the globe. Services include but are not limited to: bulk international mail; standard international mail; sorted and unsorted mail; secured international mail; undelivered mail; and some bespoke requirements as defined by the contracting body.
Region: North East,North West,Yorkshire and the Humber,East Midlands,West Midlands,East of England,London,South East,South West,Scotland,Wales

Title: In House Postal System
Description:
The Course Enquiry Unit uses it’s own in-house postal despatch office, so that prospectuses can be packed and despatched as quickly as possible, to enable a 24 hour turnaround and a speedy/high quality response to our course enquirers. 

The services consist of:

Post of prospectus and course brochures - despatch to UK, Europe and ROW, on a daily basis. Minimum sorting is required (reducing admin and time) and daily scheduled pickup by post handler (without prior appointment).

Business response services/freepost services for incoming marketing surveys and campaigns.

Bulk mailings of nurturing publicity including education/mailsort discounts – handled by external mailing agents, but charged to an online account.

Collection every day required from ML building, regardless of number of items.

No/low sorting required – items going overseas can be bagged together, saving time and administration work.

Title: Provision of internal courier services
Description:
The Supplier must provide a Next Day service offering daily secure Visits to all the Sites. The types and volumes of Items will vary at each of the Sites.
The Customer requires that each Site receives a scheduled timed Visit within the constraints provided, which must be adhered to at all times. 
The Supplier will not be required to make Collections and Deliveries at weekends or UK / Northern Ireland bank holidays other than by special arrangement. Where office closures on a bank holiday differ between England & Wales and Scotland, Visits should continue to Sites that are not affected by the bank holiday. 

The Supplier will be required to provide pre-arranged Same Day point to point Collection and Delivery on an ad hoc basis upon request from the Customer. 
Where the Customer requires an ad hoc Same Day Collection and Delivery, a minimum of 24 hours' notice will be provided. Within 4 Working Hours of receipt of the request, the Supplier must provide the Customer with a quote for the service using the information provided. The Visit will take place on a pre-arranged date and/or time. On occasion the Visit may take place at the weekend.The Supplier must provide appropriate, secure, hard sided vehicles (unless otherwise specified by the Customer) in relation to the size, type and weight of the Items in transit, giving consideration to any Site access limitations and specific requirements detailed on the request.
Attachments: Courier Contract REDACTED.pdf Invitation To Tender.zip

Title: Down Stream Access Service
Description:
HMRC has a Customer Direct Agreement with Royal Mail group (RMG) and requires Downstream Access to Royal Mail's services under Condition 9 of RMGs postal licence.
HMRC Require:
1. The successful collection and delivery in accordance with agreed standards of pre-sorted post from agreed HMRC sites to Royal Mail
2. The successful collection, sortation and delivery of unsorted post from agreed HMRC sites to Royal mail.
The supplier shall ensure that any of their systems or processes critical to the injection of mail into Royal Mail's delivery stream are integrated with those of HMRC's chosen print service provider or providers and shall undertake due diligence as part of any site visits and/or supplier days to identify to HMRC any technical or cost dependencies which may impact the ability of the supplier to achieve integration.

Title: THE SUPPLY OF ELECTORAL PRINTED STATIONERY
Description:
A Consortium of eight local Councils within Nottinghamshire is undertaking a joint procurement exercise. This is on behalf of and under the direction of their individual Returning Officers and Electoral Registration Officers for the procurement of electoral printed stationery with a view of achieving administrative and financial benefits by working together and in partnership with the successful Contractor. 
	
The Councils are seeking an experienced and established provider of electoral printed stationery. Broxtowe Borough Council is acting as lead buyer for the Consortium, which includes Ashfield District Council, Bassetlaw District Council, Broxtowe Borough Council, Gedling Borough Council, Mansfield District Council, Newark and Sherwood District Council, Nottingham City Council, and Rushcliffe Borough Council. 

Lots
The tender is split into two Lots. You may bid for all, few or just one Lot. There are no restrictions. Each Lot will be awarded independently of the others and there is no restrictions on the number of Lots that you can be awarded.

Lot 1) Requirements for Elections
Lot 2) Requirements for Canvassing / Electoral Registration and other day to day activities.

Lot 1 includes:
•	Ordinary Poll Cards
•	Postal Poll Cards
•	Empty Property Poll Cards
•	Postal Voting Packs
•	Ballet Papers
•	Tendered Ballot Papers

The printing of poll cards and postal vote poll cards for the purpose of all elections and referenda during the Contract Period for dispatch by Royal Mail or other providers, or returned to Councils for hand delivery. 

The printing of all ballot papers for all elections and referenda held during the Contract Period. 

The printing of Postal Voting Packs (including outer envelope, Envelope A, Envelope B, Postal Vote Statement, instruction sheet) and associated mail house functions including their loading, sealing and posting via a postal provider or returned to the relevant Council for in-house loading for all elections and referenda during the Contract Period. 

Lot 2 includes:

•	Annual Canvas - Initial Mail (HEFs)
•	Annual Canvas - Reminder Mail (HEFs)
•	Annual Canvas - Final Reminder (HEFs)
•	Annual Canvas - Initial to Register (ITRs)
•	Annual Canvas - Reminder to Register (ITRs)
•	Annual Canvas - Final Reminder to Register ((ITRs)
•	Postal Vote Applications

The printing of voter registration forms (Household Enquiry Forms HEFs and Invitations to Register ITRs) information leaflets and envelopes for the purpose of the annual canvass; and associated mail house functions including their loading, sealing and posting via a postal provider or to be returned to the local authority for hand delivery - to be approved by the individual Councils.

The printing and posting out of day to day correspondence via a hybrid mail service on an ad hoc basis.
Attachments: Part 1 - Instructions and Conditions of Tender.pdf Part 2 - Specification.pdf Part 3 - Tender Response.doc Part 4 - Price List.xls Part 5 - EPS2017 Contract.pdf Part 6 - INTENTION TO TENDER.docx Annex A - Councils and Wards.docx Annex B - Data Processing Agreement.doc Annex C - Quantities and Requirements.xls Annex D - Ordinary Poll Card.pdf Annex E - Postal Poll Card.pdf Annex F- Empty Property Poll Card.PDF Annex G - HEF Annual Canvass Form.pdf Annex H - HEF Empty Property From.pdf Annex I - ITR - Initial Form - needs to be black and white.pdf

Title: Sheffield City Region: Printing of the Mayoral Booklet for Sheffield City Region Combined Authority Mayoral Election 2018
Description: Sheffield City Region is inviting responses for the printing of (1) the Combined Authority Mayoral Election 2018 information booklet (2) covering letter and (3) mailing envelops for distribution of the said booklets. We require an experienced printer to produce approximately 1,013,000 booklets, covering letters and mailing envelops in accordance with the timetable detailed in the ITT and the conditions of contract and deliver to Royal Mail as instructed by CARO.  The booklets must be delivered in accordance with the timescales as prescribed by legislation.  Failure to do so is likely to invalidate the election.  Accordingly, bidders are requested to note that completion deadlines for printing are absolutely crucial to the performance of this contract and cannot be extended under any circumstances.  The mail out deadline is 13th April 2018 All election printing must comply with the relevant legislation and guidance issued by the Cabinet Office and the Electoral Commission.

Title: RFQ for Provision of Printing and Processing of The Brindley Brochure
Description:
Halton Borough Council is looking for a Supplier to provide a printing and processing service for the Brindley Brochure, which will lead to the delivery of the Mailing List.  

The main purpose of the 'Brindley Brochure' is to keep customers updated on any up and coming shows, events or facilities available at the Brindley Arts Centre.

The circulation and delivery of the brochure is a vital service for the centre as it generates business and successfully advertises the events taking place over the coming months.

The Brindley Brochure (see pdf attached) is currently produced as a 40 page, A5 brochure, weight 74g. 

The Supplier must be able to print the 35,000 brochures as per the specification requirements below: -

•	Finished Size: A5.
•	Extent: Cover: 4 Pages, Text: 40 Pages.
•	Repro: Print ready PDF's supplied.
•	Proofs: PDF Proofs.
•	Printing: Cover: 4-colour process + sealer both sides.
•	Text: 40 pages 4-colour process + sealer both sides.
•	Paper: Cover: Silk 200gsm, Text: 36 Pages Silk 115gsm.
•	Finishing: Trim to size, fold, collate, saddle stitch 2 wires and trim.

The Supplier must be able to process the 14,000 brochures in line with the requirements outlined below: -

•	Produce labels for the mailing list from an Excel Document (provided)
•	Data Processing & Mail Sorting
•	Enclosing & Polywrapping
•	Postage - Royal Mail 2nd Class

Title: CE3878 Print & Design Framework
Description: The London Borough of Tower Hamlets (the Council) is seeking to establish a print and design procurement framework (Framework) for the supply of a wide range of printing and reprographic services to the Council and the specified London Councils, and occasionally some creative design services as commensurate to the Council's or the London Council's requirements. London Borough of Newham and London Borough of Havering have expressed an interest in accessing services through this framework. Tenderers should note that there is no guarantee that any of the other named London Councils will use the framework and that no Council shall commit to any minimum expenditure under the Framework; it is the decision of each London Council whether they wish to enter into a contract and if so, for how long. Information about specific systems and processes used during the print buying process will also vary between London councils. The framework agreement will enable the Council to procure printing (and occasionally design) using this Framework, where each request shall be subject to a mini-competition, obtaining quotes using the relevant London Council's preferred ordering system. For London Borough of Tower Hamlets, print procurement, including pricing and the placement of orders, will be managed via a web-based project management system, designed to reduce waste and to produce best value and best quality printing services for the Council's print users. Examples of the type of work to be commissioned through the Framework include (but is not limited to) leaflets, posters, folders, booklets, brochures, banners, cards, business stationery, display graphics and stands, secure printing products and controlled stationery, all of varying formats, shapes, sizes and finishes. This list is not exhaustive and the Framework is designed for suppliers to be able to supply any type of print and print-related service to the Council. The framework is divided into the following lots: 1. Digital printing: e.g. for range of brochures, posters, folders, cards, leaflets, questionnaires and other council literature in various sizes and formats; direct marketing materials and any other items 2. Mailing and fulfilment: e.g. Mailing services or door-to-door distribution for direct marketing materials (e.g. brochures, publications or accompanying letters to select resident addresses); or preparing mail for delivery by Royal Mail and other delivery providers 3. Large format, including print for outdoor advertising: e.g. large format posters, external banners, internal and external signage 4. Lithographic printing: e.g. for a range of brochures, posters, folders, cards, leaflets, questionnaires and other council literature in various sizes and fo..(view full details to see more)

Title: Heat Mapping and Energy Master Planning in Reading Town Centre  - AWARD
Description:
Reading Borough Council is seeking consultants to undertake a heat mapping exercise with a focus on future development sites in Reading's Town Centre. This includes energy master planning for combined heat and power, district heating and decentralised power opportunities for Reading. 
      
      Reading Town Centre is experiencing an accelerated development growth and there is consideration for Decentralised Heating in a number of schemes (eg. Kenavon Dr L&Q, Station Hill and Royal Mail) but more work needs to be done in terms of options for location of Energy Centres and potential for connectivity. 
      
      Heat networks have been identified by the UK government as an important part of the UK's future low carbon energy supply. They are particularly well suited to areas with high density and diverse potential consumers.  
      
      The development of heat networks is also viewed as a way of addressing issues around security of energy supply, reduction of fuel poverty, economic development and the creation of a potential revenue stream.
      
      The study is needed in order to provide evidence base of the potential of district heating in new development and to assess high level technical and financial feasibility of future schemes in the context of a the new Local Plan currently being reviewed.
